div.p: This paper investigates drive-response synchronization of a class of neural networks with time-varying delays and discontinuous activations. Discontinuous state feedback controller and adaptive controller are designed such that the considered model can realize exponential complete synchronization. Moreover, the convergence rate is explicitly estimated when state feedback control is utilized. The obtained results are also applicable to neural networks with continuous activations since they are a special case of neural networks with discontinuous activations. Results of this paper improve corresponding ones which only quasi-synchronization can be achieved for neural networks with discontinuous activations. Finally, numerical simulations are given to verify the effectiveness of the theoretical results.

It is shown that neural networks exhibit chaotic behavior provided that parameters and delays are appropriately chosen (see [21] and [22]). Therefore, in recent years, synchronization and control of neural networks has been one of the hot research topics (see [23]- [28] etc). In [2], authors investigated quasi-synchronization of discontinuous neural networks with and without parameter mismatches, i.e., synchronization error can only be controlled to a small region around zero, but cannot approach zero. Results of [2] demonstrated that, under the classical state feedback controller, complete synchronization cannot be realized even without parameter mismatch between the drive and response systems due to the discontinuity of activation function. It is well known that one of the most important applications of chaos synchronization is in secure communication. When chaos synchronization is applied to secure communication, only if the master and response systems achieve complete synchronization can the transmitted signal be fingered out. Therefore, it is necessary to study complete synchronization of neural networks with discontinuous activations. In [14], complete synchronization of discontinuous neural networks was investigated via approximation and linear matrix inequality (LMI) approach. But we find that, through the approximation approach used in [14], the control gain may be very large, which leads to inapplicable in practice. Hence, it is urgent to design new controller to achieve complete synchronization of neural networks with discontinuous neuron activations.

Being motivated by the above analysis, this paper aims to investigate global exponential synchronization of delayed neural networks with discontinuous activation functions via two control methods: state feedback control and adaptive control. Different from the controllers in [2] and [14], both discontinuous state feedback control and discontinuous adaptive control are designed. Without using Halanay inequality, this paper reveals that the considered model can realize complete drive-response synchronization under the designed controllers. The discontinuous activations are assumed to satisfy a growth condition, which includes continuous activations as a special case, and hence the results of this paper are also applicable to neural networks with continuous activations. Under the framework of Filippov solution [30], by using Lyapunov function and chain rule of differential inclusion, rigorous proofs are given for the exponential stability of the error systems of the coupled systems. Numerical simulations show the effectiveness of the theoretical results.

Some necessary assumptions, definitions and lemmas are also given in this section. Our main results and their rigorous proofs are described in Section III. In Section IV, two examples with their numerical simulations are provided to show the effectiveness of our results. In Section V, conclusions are given.

However, control gains of the state feedback controller obtained by theoretical analysis are usually much larger than needed in practice, which will increase control cost. In the following, we shall consider adaptive controllers corresponding to the state feedback controllers in Theorems 1 and 2, and get Theorems 3 and 4 respectively.

Remark 2: In the above results, exponential synchronization criteria are derived. However, Theorems 1 and 2 can explicitly estimate the convergence rate, but the Theorems 3 and 4 cannot. This is because synchronization velocity increases accelerately under adaptive controller and is dependent on the constants and initial value of . Remark 3: When the activation function is continuous, the constants become zero. In this case, the state feedback controller and adaptive controller are also effective. Hence, the results of this paper are applicable to neural networks with both discontinuous and continuous activations.

Remark 4: In the proofs of the above results, we do not use the well known Halanay inequality. Moreover, the Lyaponov functionals utilized are simple and the adaptive laws do not include the exponential function , which is needed in [36] and [37].

Remark 5: Under the designed controllers (both state feedback controller and adaptive controller), exponential synchronization criteria between systems (1) and ( 8) are derived in this paper. The synchronization criteria in this paper are simple and can be easily verified in practice. However, under the controller utilized in [2], the authors only got the quasi-synchronization criteria. By using the approximation approach, the authors in [14] obtained asymptotic synchronization criteria. But the control gains obtained in [14] may approach infinity, which leads to inapplicable in practice. Recently, authors in [38] investigated synchronization of linearly coupled dynamical networks with non-Lipschitz right-hand sides. But the discontinuous functions [38] were weakened to be weak-QUAD and semi-QUAD, which means that the discontinuous function approaches to a continuous function as time goes, and the criteria were expressed in integral inequalities. Such synchronization criteria may be not easily verified in practice, especially in the case that there are countable discontinuities for the discontinuous functions. To sum up, results of this paper improve those in [2], [14], and [38] to some extent.

Moreover, exponential synchronization is realized by adding the state feedback controller (11) or the adaptive controller (25) to the response system. However, results and numerical simulations in [2] only get quasi-synchronization under the linear state feedback controller (see Remark 6, Corollary 2, and Figs. 8-10 in Example 3 in the [2]). From the proofs of Theorems 1-3 and the numerical simulations one can see that the part in the controller (11) plays a key role in dealing with the state differences between the driver and response systems. Therefore, theoretical results and numerical simulations in this paper improve those in [2].

V. CONCLUSION Both the issues of chaos synchronization and stability of neural networks with discontinuous neuron activations have intrigued increasing interests of researchers from different fields. However, few published papers consider synchronization control of neural networks with discontinuous activations. Hence, this paper study the exponential synchronization of neural networks with discontinuous activations. Both state feedback control and adaptive control techniques are considered. The designed controllers are simple and can be applied to neural networks with discontinuous and continuous activations. Compared with existing results which only quasi-synchronization can be realized, the obtained results of this paper are better. Numerical simulations show that the theoretical results are effective.
